1. A mass with no force applied doesn't change its velocity. If it comes to rest, it is because there are invisible forces like friction, air drag or even electromagnetic forces that make it decelerate.
2. An object with mass m and an applied constant force will accelerate and continue so until this force is counteracted by an opposite force like air drag, friction. Aceleration is defined by force divided by mass (a=F/m). Acceleration is the rate at which speed changes. Only when the force balances with an opposite equal force (resulting net force is zero) the speed stays constant.
3. A force between a big object and a small object like gravity between earth and moon, or a collision between a truck and a car is the same on both objects, just in opposite direction. The moon falls towards the earth (if there was not an outward force due to its rotation around earth) more rapidly than earth falls to the moon due to its much lower mass. The car gets decelerated more rapidly in an impact than the truck due to its lower mass. The truck also gets slowed down but way less. Thats why it can continue to push the car.

The third incorrect law isn't entirely incorrect. Even though the collision force is the same for everything involved due to it just being a sum of the other forces, it is true that (assuming same speed) a larger object is providing more of the force in that total than a smaller object, and then, due again to the sizes, the effects of that force will be greater on the smaller object than on the larger one. To use the next example, Earth's gravitational force is, undeniably, greater than the gravitational force of the Moon, and the Moon's path is more affected by the combined force than the Earth's is.

So, from a practical standpoint, the third incorrect law might as well be correct. We just know it isn't from a mathematical perspective.

A larger mass object moving has a greater momentum than a smaller mass object moving with equal velocity. Thus, if a larger mass object were to be stopped completely to at rest by a smaller object, the impulse to stop it would, for example, be equal to a larger force times one second versus a smaller force times one second for if a smaller mass object were to be stopped completely to at rest by a larger object. Since the force exerted by the other object on to the first is exerted back with equal magnitude, a larger object does exert a larger force on a smaller object and smaller object exerts a smaller force on a larger object, at least when it comes to stopping the masses to at rest.

The real laws:

1. An object in motion will remain in motion and an object at rest tends to stay in rest unless acted upon by an outside force.
2. F=ma (a net, unbalanced force acted upon an object causes the object to accelerate in the direction of the force).
3. Every action has a equal but opposite reaction.

Please correct me if I'm wrong but the correct laws of motion are:
1. An object with no unbalanced forces acting on it will naturally stay in motion. (An object in motion/at rest tends to stay in motion/at rest unless acted upon by an outside force).
2. An unbalanced force causes an object to move with a constant acceleration (rate of change of speed with respect to time). NOT VELOCITY! If velocity is constant then acceleration is zero, but if the force is nonzero, the acceleration must also be nonzero by (Force vector)=(mass scalar)*(acceleration vector).
3.Larger objects apply equal forces to smaller objects. Due to my weight, I am applying a force onto the Earth, but the Earth is also exerting a normal force back to me. The forces are of equal magnitude and opposite directions so the net force is zero. Because the net force is zero, my net acceleration is also zero.

So we have (p1 + p2)/(m1 + m2) = final velocity of both vehicles.  Now this is an idealized model where there is no rebounding or conversion of kinetic energy into things like sound, heat, etc... They just hit and then become effectively a single object moving off.  We can complicate this model by introducing elasticity through the coefficient of restitution but I will leave that as an exercise for the reader =)

Having said that, Kinetic Energy is not a vector, so it has no direction.  You are correct that the truck has greater kinetic energy however. If we assume inelastic collision we can find the post-collision direction by adding the pre-collision momentum of each vehicle and then dividing that sum by the sum of their mass.  We can find their momentum's individually by multiplying mass times velocity (no extra factors just p=mv, where p is momentum). Note that p is the greek letter Rho.

You are correct that kinetic energy is tied to mass and velocity, the formula is KE = (1/2)mv^2.  Or in words (since formulas don't show well here) Kinetic Energy is equal to one half of the product of the velocity squared times the mass. Note typically this equation is expressed with units of KE in joules, mass in kilograms, and velocity in meters per second.  And KE is an expression of how much energy is stored in an object due to the velocity its mass is currently propelled to.

(Corrected Law #3) : Going back to your formula where Acceleration equals Force divided by mass (a=F/m [or] F=ma).  When the two vehicles strike the  "impact force" applies to both equally (they act on each other in equal and opposite fashion). So b/c the applied forces are the same but the masses are different the accelerations are also different. The truck, having more mass, accelerates less as a result of the impact and thus the "jerk" (rate of change in acceleration)  results in less injury.

For those wondering: (Corrected Law #2) His equation is again wrong, it is Force = Mass * Acceleration which can also be written Acceleration = Force / Mass. (note the arrows above Force and V in the video indicate these values are vectors or in other words they are in a defined direction, in the real equation Force and Acceleration are in fact vectors).  So an unbalanced force causes an object to accelerate (i.e. change velocity) not to move at constant velocity.

First incorrect law: Take the cup sliding on the counter. The law assumed no external force was applied. Yet there are actually two(significant) forces on the cup. A gravitational force downward, which causes friction and a frictional force opposite the direction of movement, which causes the glass to slow down and stop. A better example would be in space. If we were to remove all gravitational forces, an object in motion would continue to move in a straight line until it hit something.

For those who don't get why they are incorrect:
1st one: he says "without any unbalanced forces", but the first two demonstrations have the force of friction. It's not hard to figure out the forces of the other ones.
2nd one: most of the car's force goes into accelerating the car; once it reaches the new speed, the car exerts very little force (only to combat friction).
3rd one: the larger and smaller objects exert the same force, but the larger object has more inertia than the smaller one.

1st law: If no force is exerted upon an object or the sum of all force vectors equals zero, the object either: Moves in a straight line and with a constant velocity; or doesn't move at all. (If sum=0, a=0)

2nd law: The sum of all forces acting upon an object is equal to the product of its mass and acceleration (F=ma)

3rd law: For every acting force there is another force equal by size, but opposite in direction. (F'=-F)

It only applies in the 'special' case within inertial reference frames.

Your fourth point - They don't "create" equal forces.  That makes it sound like they create equal gravitational fields, and that is not the case.  The moon exerts the same gravitational force on the Earth as the Earth exerts on the moon - - in the opposite direction.  For example, the gravitational force the moon exerts on a 10 kg mass is less than the force the Earth exerts on that same mass.  This does not fit your claim that they "create" equal forces.  Just between each other is it equal.

Your third point - It is not the mass of the object exerting the force that is relevant (unless you are talking about gravity - and only gravity).  It is the mass of the object on which the force is being exerted that is relevant.  If a truck and a car collide, the force the truck exerts is equal and opposite to the force the car exerts.  The mass of the car is less, so that force has a greater effect on the car.  So the accelerations are different; forces are the same.

Now, what might be confusing to you is this.  If I push your chest with a force of 200 Newtons, then your chest will also exert a force on my hands of 200 Newtons in the opposite direction to my original force.  This is what people mean by the "forces being the same".  They only mean the force that which is the equal and opposite (to make a force pair) to any force.  ALL forces have an equal and opposite counter part.  They don't mean that every force is equal.

Force is in Newtons
Mass is in kilograms
Acceleration is in m/s²

These are just the SI units.  There are other units that can be used, but the SI units are the most familiar to me (and most others).

So if you apply a force of 5 Newtons to a mass of 1 kg, the resulting acceleration will be a=5/1 = 5 m/s².

If you observe a mass of 10 kg being accelerated at 10 m/s² and want to know what force is being applied, then F=(10)(10) = 100 Newtons.  

Force isn't constant or anything.

The SI unit for energy is the Joule.  The SI unit for force is the Newton.  1 Joule is the amount of energy expended (this is 'work done') by applying a force of 1 Newton for 1 meter.  So a unit of energy is just force/distance.  There are many forms of energy so your question cannot really be answered universally.  However, as it relates to velocity, you have kenetic energy, which is just the amount of energy required to accelerate a given mass to a given velocity.  In this case E(k) = 1/2mv².

Newton's first law of motion (the law of inertia): An object will continue with its state of motion if no external forces act upon it.

Newton's second law of motion: Force is the product of mass and acceleration. Put simply F=ma

Newton's third law of motion: If object A exerts a force on object B the object B will exert a force on object A equal in magnitude but opposite in direction. Simply put: every action has an equal and opposite reaction.

If you exert a force on any object it will exert an equal force back, but that doesn’t mean you can’t move forward, as the force of friction you make with the ground can cancel out that force and push you forward. Sometimes, if the object is really heavy or the ground is slippery, there won’t be enough friction and the object will push you back. Note the two forces do not cancel each other out (the force you exert on the object and the force it exerts on you), as they act on different things.

This is an objects resistance to change in motion.  If you have a mass of 70 kg and you push a 5 kg object.  The force you put on that object is the same exact force that object puts on you.  The reason the object moves, while you don't move much is because the force being applied affects a 5 kg object a lot more than a 70 kg object.  If you tried pushing a 500 kg object, now the force affects YOU more than it does the 500 kg object, and you would move instead of the 500 kg object.

Here's why his 3 laws are incorrect:
1. These objects in the video are coming to a rest because of friction, air resistance or hitting another object. Think of an example with no outer forces, like a rock moving through outer-space, it will stay moving forever. (Newton law 1)
2. Force=mass x acceleration. So an unbalanced force will cause constant acceleration, not velocity. (Law 2)
3. Every time an object exerts a force on another object, that object exerts an exactly equal force back. (Law 3)

Second Law: Again referring to the equilibrium of the force i.e. If the forces are balanced the object will either remain at rest or travel with constant velocity. An unbalanced force will cause an acceleration to the object, either acting against it (deceleration or negative acceleration) or acting along with it (positive acceleration)

Friction is an unbalanced force that causes an object to slow down and come to rest. Because Newton stated that an object moving at a constant velocity will have a balanced force ie. Net Force = 0 But when an unbalanced force is acted on the object it will cause it to come to rest. Which is important out when solving problems such as projectile motion because we have to assume friction is negligible therefore the Net force is 0 meaning the object is in equilibrium.
